Thx, I'm going to explain whats happening here:

On opening a dialog (by clicking the Configure button), that loads the settings for a particular filter, then clicking the Submit button, we save the form field values from the dialog to an array keyed by the filter name with values keyed by the field name (eg

  - filter_url (
      filter_url_length: 72
    )

then this is saved to Backdrop.settings.filter_settings.

So the JS code that runs when a dialog is closed: 

// When you click the submit button and the AJAX completes
$(".filter-dialog .ui-dialog-buttonpane .button-primary").click(function (e) {
    $(document).ajaxComplete(function() {
      // Check backdrop.settings.filter_settings: only index here will be `filter_url`
      $.each(Backdrop.settings.filterSettings, function( index, value ) {
        // Check each member; index_too here will be `filter_url_length` 
        $.each(value, function( index_too, value_too ) {
          // Find the `filter_url_length` field on the underlying page, in the #filterorder table 
          item = '#filterorder input[name="filters['+index+'][filter][settings][' + index_too + ']"]';
          // And set the value from the dialog
          setInputValue($(item), value_too);

When you open a dialog

$(window).on('dialog:aftercreate', function (e, dialog, $element, settings) {
  // the first time Backdrop.settings.filter_settings wont be set yet (cause its set when you first click the Submit button)
  if (Backdrop.settings.filterSettings) {
    // Get the filter name of the filter whose Configure button was just clicked. 
    filter_name = $('#backdrop-modal').find('.filter-dialog-settings').once('filter-editor-status').attr('data-filter-name');
    // Backdrop.settings.filter_settings will have values from the last time you clicked Submit
    filter_values = Backdrop.settings.filterSettings[filter_name];
    // Transfer those values to the dialog fields.
    $.each(filter_values, function( index, value ) {
      $item = $('input[name="' + index + '"]');
      setInputValue($item, value);
I've never seen this done anywhere, but its the only way I could think of to get it done without changing how filters are saved

To be explicit, this: "Large iPads, for example, currently use the hover effect even though they are Touch-screen devices." How?

@docwilmot to answer your question: no, you cannot hover on touch devices, unless you are using a mouse (think laptops like MS Surface and the likes, which are still large-screen devices, support touch/pen, but people also connect mice to them). Hover with touch can only be "simulated" ...to elaborate on that, the current "Use a click to open, instead of a hover" option will have the following result, depending on device:

  • devices with mice/pointer support: mouse hover will not expand the menu; you need to click once to expand, and then a second time to visit the link
  • touch-only devices w/o pointer: hover is not possible; you need to tap once to expand, and then a second time to visit the link
THat makes sense. Followup question though: why do we mention screen size? Have we confirmed that a small non-touchscreen devices will always open the menu on hover?
That's why @Olaf Grabienski is suggesting this wording instead I guess: Touch-screen devices always open on touch.
...which might also be incorrect in cases like touch-enabled laptops with mice connected.
Right but we can confirm this behavior has nothing to do with size, only touch-enabled-ness?

And that this suggestion is the most accurate so far: https://github.com/backdrop/backdrop-issues/issues/4253#issuecomment-570175116
